metadata.title: Fuzzy physics-informed thermal diagnostics via non-invasive frequency-domain signature distillation in high-energy-density batteries

si2.svg svg 20327 ALTIMG JECHEM 4954 S2095-4956(25)00672-2 10.1016/j.jechem.2025.08.018 Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Fig. 1 Comparison of model-based, data-driven, and fuzzy physics-informed approaches. Schematics of electrochemical processes within lithium-ion batteries and representative measurable electric signals. The fuzzy physics-informed framework introduces a paradigm that isolates dominant electrochemical processes as governing physical constraints while disregarding redundant constraints, thereby generating an explicit reduced-order mapping that enables accelerating temperature estimation. Fig. 2 Frequency domain analysis for isolating thermally sensitive electrochemical processes. (a) Illustration of ECM and corresponding physical significance in the DRT framework. (d, g) Methodology of explicit determination of effective resistances associated with distinct processes, each governed by unique relaxation timescales. Comparison of explicit determination (solid-color lines) and implicit regression (light-color lines) for estimating process-specific resistances under heterogeneous operational conditions for LFP 18650 cells (b) with 20 % SOC and (c) with 100 % SOC; galvanostatically cycled to (e) 81 % SOH and (f) 70 °C thermally degraded, and for coin-type cells with (h) NCM (i) and LCO as cathode materials. Error bars for implicit regression reflect uncertainties from nonlinear least-squares fitting. Explicit determination aligns quantitatively with trends derived from implicit regression while exhibiting superior robustness and reduced variability across operational conditions. Fig. 3 Spectral distributions of characteristic frequencies derived from equivalent circuit modeling. (a) Characteristic frequency distributions for LFP 18650 cells under various conditions: 20 % SOC, 100 % SOC, galvanostatically cycled to 81 % SOH, and 70 °C thermally degraded. Delineated frequency domains for (b) R 1,eff and (c) R 2,eff for LFP 18650 cells. (d) Characteristic frequency distributions for coin-type cells: 2032-type NCM, 2032-type LCO, 2450-type NCM, and 2450-type LCO. Delineated frequency domains for (e) R 1,eff and (f) R 2,eff for coin-type cells. Fig. 4 Thermal response characteristics of the fuzzy variable (R eff). Contour maps depict (a, c, e, g) R eff distributions and (b, d, f, h) thermal dependency analyses across temperature and frequency domains for LFP 18650 cells under distinct operating states: (a, b) 20 % SOC, (c, d) 100 % SOC, (e, f) galvanostatically cycled to 81 % SOH, and (g, h) 70 °C thermally degraded. Corresponding analyses for coin-type cells: (i, j) 2032-type NCM and (k, l) 2032-type LCO. Fig. 5 Cross-scenario generalizability for normalized R eff. (a–c, g–i) Arrhenius regression analysis and (d–f, j–l) residual errors derived from mono-condition calibration subsets for LFP 18650 cells with (a, d) 20 % SOC, (b, e) 100 % SOC, (c, f) galvanostatic cycled to 81 % SOH, and (g, j) 70 °C thermally degraded, and those for coin-type cells [(h, k) 2032-type NCM and (i, l) 2032-type LCO]. Ordinary least-squares fitting with 95 % probabilistic prediction intervals: (m, o) multi-condition subsets of 18650-type cells and (n, p) subsets of NCM/LCO coin cells. Fig. 6 Operational validation of fuzzy physics-informed internal temperature monitoring. (a) Stepwise current charging protocol (0, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, and 2.0 A; 3-minute dwell intervals). (b) Thermal transient profiling under controlled cooling (50 to 30 °C). (c) Galvanostatic cycling protocol within operational 20 %–80 % SOC. (d) Irregular current pulse sequence. Fig. 7 Comparison of fuzzy physics-informed, single-frequency, and full-spectra approaches. (a–c) The fuzzy physics-informed approach exhibits monotonic thermal response characteristics with sub-second acquisition times (<1 s), enabling robust real-time temperature monitoring. (d–f) Single-frequency impedance parameters—including real (e) and imaginary (f) components—exhibit significant signal fluctuations despite millisecond-scale temporal resolution. (g–i) Full-spectra impedance-derived parameters [SEI resistance via ECM (h) and DRT function (i)] are quantitatively consistent with the fuzzy physics-informed approach but necessitate multi-minute spectral acquisition and computationally intensive non-linear regressions, rendering them operationally fragile. Fuzzy physics-informed thermal diagnostics via non-invasive frequency-domain signature distillation in high-energy-density batteries Zhenkang Lin Writing – original draft Visualization Validation Software Methodology Investigation Data curation Jing Yang Investigation Formal analysis Chunyu Li Writing – review & editing Shilong Wang Writing – review & editing Wenzhong Cong Writing – review & editing Teng Li Writing – review & editing Lin Qi Writing – review & editing Kening Sun Writing – review & editing Cheng Fan Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Beijing Key Laboratory of Chemical Power Source and Green Catalysis, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China Beijing Key Laboratory of Chemical Power Source and Green Catalysis School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Beijing Institute of Technology Beijing 100081 China Beijing Key Laboratory of Chemical Power Source and Green Catalysis, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A fuzzy physics-informed framework groups thermally sensitive processes by relaxation timescale, eliminating decoupling needs and redundant constraints for early thermal anomaly detection with high accuracy and minimal latency across varying states of charge and health. Accurate real-time monitoring of internal temperature in lithium-ion batteries remains critical for preventing thermal runaway, as conventional approaches sacrifice either computational efficiency or cross-scenario robustness. We present a generalized fuzzy physics-informed framework that distills thermally sensitive electrochemical processes while circumventing redundant physical constraints, thereby establishing an explicit mechanism-constrained mapping between frequency-domain signals and internal temperature. This framework facilitates online thermal estimation, with dynamic validations in LiFePO4/graphite 18650-type cells confirming real-time capability with near-instantaneous acquisition (∼6 s per measurement), exceptional accuracy (±0.5 °C) within the operational temperature range (30–50 °C), and operational resilience across 20 %–80 % state-of-charge. The framework maintains predictive fidelity (±1.0 °C at 30 °C and ±4.0 °C at 60 °C, 95 % prediction intervals) across 80 %–100 % state-of-health while demonstrating adaptability to cathode materials and structural architectures. This strategy resolves the competing imperatives of physical interpretability, computational efficiency, and cross-scenario generalizability, offering a universal paradigm for embedded thermal management in safety-critical applications. Keywords Lithium-ion batteries Thermal diagnostics Non-invasive characterizations Fuzzy physics-informed methods Frequency domain signatures 1 Introduction Accurately estimating the internal temperature of a lithium-ion battery (LIB) serves as the cornerstone of battery safety management [1–3], making it the final safeguard against thermal runaway. The real-time monitoring of internal temperature via robust and generalized strategy has become essential for practical applicability to ensure timely decision-making and prevent catastrophic failures [4,5]. Despite its critical importance for thermal management, direct measurement of internal temperatures in commercial LIBs remains impractical due to their hermetically sealed architecture. Invasive thermal monitoring strategies, such as embedded micro sensors [6–9], are economically prohibitive and pose operational risks [10], confining practical diagnostics to surface thermometry. However, surface-derived thermal data exhibit pronounced temporal latency for real-time thermal state tracking, particularly under fast-charge protocols that provoke acute thermal transients within LIBs [11–14]. Concurrently, indirect inference of internal temperature via accessible thermally dependent electrical signals [15–18]—predominantly current, voltage, and impedance—confronts intrinsic complexities. These signals inherently convolve thermal states with electrochemical dynamics, fundamentally impeding the isolation of spatially averaged internal temperatures from measurements. Two principal methodologies have been developed to deconvolve thermal states from quantifiable datasets. Model-based approaches [19,20] augment measurable parameters with physical constraints to identify an intermediary variable that is both physically interpretable and demonstrates pronounced sensitivity to—and quantitative dependence on—internal temperature. This is achieved by harmonization of said variable and empirical measurements within mathematical frameworks encapsulating thermodynamic and kinetic behaviors of the battery, thereby enabling adaptable model generalization across analogous systems via minimal structural modifications. Nevertheless, the implementation of such model-based approaches for real-time monitoring is impeded by computational intractability, as governing equations frequently entail implicit, high-order nonlinear partial differential equations that render parameter estimation prohibitively resource-intensive [21,22]. Conversely, data-driven models [18,23,24] circumvent these limitations by establishing explicit functional mappings between measurable signals (e.g., current and voltage) and internal temperature through statistical or machine learning algorithms. Such explicit formulations permit rapid evaluation under conditions congruent with online monitoring requirements, while their exclusive reliance on directly observable inputs underscores practical utility. However, their efficacy is compromised by an inherent deficiency: multicollinearity among input signals and the absence of physical constraints compress the effective dimensionality below that required to capture the full spectrum of electrochemical processes governing temperature dynamics. This renders the inverse problem of temperature estimation both ill-posed and ill-conditioned [25–27]. Consequently, these models suffer from fragile robustness within operational bounds and deficient extrapolative generalization, culminating in prohibitive temporal and economic expenditures. Any modification to battery chemistry, thermal management protocols, or environmental conditions necessitates exhaustive retraining with extensive high-fidelity labeled datasets [28], further diminishing their viability. Diverging from conventional paradigms that seek to establish physically constrained or statistical mappings between measurable signals and internal temperature—approaches frequently incapable of simultaneously satisfying the rigorous tripartite demands of real-time monitoring, broad generalization, and operational robustness across both model-based and data-driven frameworks—this work proposes a novel methodology designated “fuzzy physics”. This approach centers on deriving a fuzzy physics-informed variable that, while not rigidly bound to precise physical interpretability, ensures quantitative alignment by preserving consistent monotonic correlations with underlying electrochemical processes. Crucially, this variable maintains a low-dimensional, mathematically explicit mapping to measurable signals, thereby enabling safe reduction of physical complexity while sustaining cross-system transferability under sparse input conditions. In this work, departing from methodologies that pursue rigorous decoupling for the overall electrochemical-related parameters with high thermal sensitivity—such as lithium-ion charge transfer kinetics or ionic transport across solid-electrolyte interphases (SEIs) [29,30]—in full-cell systems through frequency- or time-domain analyses like equivalent circuit modeling (ECM) [31,32] or distribution of relaxation times (DRT) [33,34], we employ a fuzzy physics-informed framework to isolate a subset of thermally responsive processes within the empirical relaxation time domain of interphase dynamics, where “fuzzy” denotes dimensionality-reduced electrochemical impedance representation that preserves the essential physical dependence on temperature while omitting non-critical physical constraints to achieve computationally efficient and robust temperature inversion. This approach designates the approximate impedance of said process cluster as a fuzzy variable, which exhibits robust correlation with SEI resistance trends as internal temperature changes. Inheriting impedance-derived physical interpretability while circumventing intricate deconvolution procedures, this low-dimensional mapping enables resilient monitoring of internal temperature transients under dynamic operational regimes. To validate this paradigm, we executed a systematically designed experimental matrix, generating—to our knowledge—the inaugural publicly available temperature-dependent electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) dataset spanning multidimensional operating parameters: state of charge (SOC; 20 %–100 %), state of health (SOH; 100 %–80 %), cathode chemistries (LiFePO4, NCM111, LiCoO2), cell configurations (18650 cylindrical vs. coin-type), and temperatures (20–90 °C) (Fig. 1 ). Within the fuzzy physics construct, experimental validation underscores the capability of the framework for real-time thermal diagnostics, achieving high temporal resolution (∼6 s) and fidelity (±0.5 °C across 30–50 °C) even during dynamic SOC variations (ΔSOC > 60 %) and acute thermal transients (0.8 °C min−1). Notably, the derived impedance variable demonstrates remarkable generalizability across all tested systems. Chemistry-specific refinements (e.g., 18650-type LiFePO4 cells) maintain thresholds of ±1.0 °C at 30 °C, with deviations progressively expanding to ±4.0 °C at 60 °C under concurrent SOC and SOH perturbations. 2 Methods 2.1 Cell preparation Cells were conditioned to predetermined SOC and SOH levels using galvanostatic charge-discharge protocols at 30 °C. For LiFePO4 (LFP) cells, cycling was performed between cutoff voltages of 2.5 V (discharge) and 3.65 V (charge). LiCoO2 (LCO) and LiNi0.33Co0.33Mn0.33O2 (NCM) cells were cycled between 2.75 and 4.2 V. The discharge capacity measured at a 1C rate served as the metric for SOH determination, with 0 % SOC defined as the voltage cutoff during discharge under these conditions. 2.2 Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy measurements Galvanostatic EIS was performed on 18650-type lithium-ion cells and coin cells at defined SOC and SOH. For 18650-type cells, a sinusoidal current perturbation with an amplitude of 0.1 A was applied across a frequency range from 10 kHz to 100 mHz. Coin cells, owing to their higher internal resistance, were subjected to a 5 mA amplitude over an extended frequency spectrum from 100 kHz to 10 mHz. During static EIS measurements, cells were equilibrated at the target temperature for 2 h to mitigate thermal heterogeneity, with a calibrated thermocouple affixed to the cell surface to monitor and correct for temperature deviations. For real-time impedance monitoring, a simplified protocol was employed: two discrete frequencies (1 kHz and 100 Hz) were sequentially applied, enabling rapid acquisition of impedance data within 6 s per scan. Surface temperature was concurrently tracked via a thermocouple during transient measurements. 2.3 Online monitoring validation The validation protocol commenced with cells instrumented at an initial SOC of ∼80 %, equipped with surface-mounted thermocouples for real-time thermal tracking. A dual-frequency EIS protocol (1 kHz and 100 Hz) was employed for continuous impedance monitoring, accompanied by a controlled discharge-charge cycling regimen to assess system fidelity under operating conditions. For thermal transition experiments, cells were first equilibrated at 50 °C for 2 h to establish thermal uniformity, after which they were rapidly transferred to a temperature-controlled environment stabilized at 30 °C. This abrupt thermal perturbation enabled characterization of the monitoring system’s responsiveness to transient thermal gradients and thermal inertia effects. 2.4 Regression and temperature reconstruction of fuzzy variable-temperature mapping The temperature-sensitive parameter R eff was operationally defined through a physics-informed normalization protocol (Eq. (1)), incorporating the differential real impedance (ΔRe) between dual-frequency measurements. A reference ΔRe value at 30.0 °C, determined via precision interpolation rather than nearest-neighbor approximation, served as the thermal calibration baseline. Arrhenius-type thermal dependence was resolved through least-squares regression of normalized R eff values against inverse temperature (1/T), with 95 % confidence prediction intervals calculated via ordinary least-squares methodology using the Python Statsmodels library. For real-time thermal reconstruction, acquired ΔRe data were normalized against the 30.0 °C reference prior to solving the temperature-dependent regression function. 2.5 Data availability Data for this article, including temperature-dependent electrochemical impedance spectroscopy datasets, complete with metadata annotations, have been deposited in https://github.com/linzk-bit/bit-eis-vary-temperature-dataset. Code for the computational framework can be found at https://github.com/linzk-bit/dualzense. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Data generation Electrochemical measurements were performed across a temperature range of 25–90 °C on commercial coin-type and 18650-type lithium-ion batteries with LFP, NCM111, and LCO cathodes, to construct a high-dimensional parameter space governing temperature-sensitive physical processes. Commercial LFP/graphite cells (18650-type, 1.2 A h) were subjected to EIS tests under controlled temperature gradients, with measurements systematically performed across varying SOC (20 %–100 %) and SOH (100 %–80 %, degraded via galvanostatic cycling at 30 °C; calendar aging at elevated temperatures of 60, 70, 80, and 90 °C). To validate the generalizability of the approach to other graphite-based lithium-ion batteries, complementary experiments were performed on LCO/graphite (2032-type, 45 mA h; 2450-type, 120 mA h) and NCM/graphite (2032-type, 40 mA h; 2450-type, 125 mA h) configurations. A comprehensive summary of cell specifications and experimental conditions is provided in Table S1, with detailed methodologies outlined in Supplementary Note S1 and Methods. The resultant multidimensional dataset integrates frequency response characteristics (from 10 kHz to 100 mHz for cylinder cells and from 100 kHz to 10 mHz for coin cells) with metadata annotations, including temperature, SOC, SOH, and structure architecture. Both the raw dataset and the Python preprocessing scripts are openly accessible, constituting—to the best of our knowledge—the first publicly available battery dataset integrating comprehensive EIS profiles under coupled thermal-electrochemical aging states. Representative Nyquist plots are illustrated in Figs. S1–S5, revealing significant dependencies of impedance features on cell specifications (cathode chemistry and nominal capacity) and operational states (SOC, SOH, and aging states). What is more, analytical complexity is compounded by inconsistent ohmic resistance shifts—attributable to contact resistance fluctuations and inductance artifacts from cell packaging and experimental fixtures—which obscure intrinsic electrochemical processes, especially at elevated temperatures. Consequently, a standardized normalization framework (Supplementary Notes S2 and S3) is employed to enable direct comparison across operational parameters (e.g., temperature, SOC, AND SOH) and account for intersystem architectural heterogeneity. 3.2 Fuzzy variable definition and mechanism-constrained low-dimensional mappings The fuzzy variable—an intermediary construct for internal temperature estimation—is formulated according to two foundational criteria: (i) incorporation of physical significance through emulation of underlying electrochemical process trajectories; (ii) establishment of a low-dimensional, mathematically explicit mapping to measurable signals, thereby circumventing regression-induced fitting uncertainty. 3.2.1 Definition of governing physical processes Identification of electrochemical processes, exhibiting robust monotonic thermal dependence while maintaining minimal confounding influences from SOC fluctuations or degradation effects is critical for the fuzzy variable specification. Given the well-established correlation between ionic transport resistance across SEI and internal temperature, we systematically evaluate its efficacy across diverse SOC, SOH, and cell architecture within the 20–70 °C operational envelope (Fig. 2 ). As illustrated in Fig. 2(a), impedance spectra are partitioned into discrete electrochemical process classes, each represented as a subset of processes characterized by continuous independent relaxation timescales. Three thermally sensitive dominant classes emerge in lithium-ion batteries’ high- and mid-frequency domains (Fig. 2d and g): millisecond-scale processes governing ionic transport at the particle/electrolyte interfaces and within SEIs, respectively, and a slower process, spanning tens of milliseconds to seconds, corresponding to charge transfer processes [35–37]. Temperature-dependent behaviors of these process resistances, quantified via the conventional ECM framework, exhibit divergent convergence characteristics (Fig. 2b, c, e, f, h, and i, light curves). In 18650-type cells (Fig. 2b, c, e, and f), ultra-high-frequency (R 1,ECM) and high-frequency (R 2,ECM) resistances demonstrate pronounced thermal sensitivity (>5 % °C−1) across 20–70 °C. This robust coupling persists in alternative architectures—coin-type LCO and NCM cells (Fig. 2h and i) maintain substantial sensitivity (>3 % °C−1) for R 1,ECM and R 2,ECM. Conversely, low-frequency resistance (R 3,ECM) demonstrates diminished thermal responsivity and heightened parametric instability due to low temperature-dependence and long measurement durations as evidenced by the small slope and large error margins of purple lines in Fig. 2, particularly evident in the thermally degraded 18650-type cells (Fig. 2f) and coin-cell configurations (Fig. 2h and i). Consequently, ionic transport processes on surfaces and within SEIs—responding frequency of order of kilohertz and relaxation time of milliseconds—constitute optimal foundational processes for fuzzy variable definition, attributable to their exceptional thermal responsivity, cross-scenario robustness, and rapid dynamics. 3.2.2 Fuzzy physics-informed dimensionality reduction How to concurrently incorporate physical significance and establish a low-dimensional explicit mapping to acquired signals is essential to implement the real-time, robust, and generalized strategy. Capitalizing on the inherent properties of EIS Nyquist plots—where the differential real impedance (ΔRe) across spectral boundaries of defined frequency windows provides a mathematically tractable surrogate for cumulative resistances of relaxation processes within corresponding time intervals—enables computationally efficient dimensionality reduction (Fig. 2d and g). As validated in Fig. 2(b, c, e, f, h, and i), derived parameters R 1,eff and R 2,eff (dark curves) exhibit near-perfect alignment with ECM-quantified resistances R 1,ECM and R 2,ECM, persisting across diverse SOC, SOH, and cathode materials. Crucially, in thermally degraded 18650-type cells (Fig. 2f) and coin-cell configurations (Fig. 2h and i), R eff faithfully tracks monotonic temperature dependence, whereas R ECM suffers from instability due to non-convergence and local optima entrapment. However, frequency windows for distinct electrochemical processes display substantial state-dependent variability [35,38], complicating precise frequency boundary distinction and risking reintroduction of nonlinear parameterization complexities and instability. As illustrated in Fig. 3 , the frequency windows of R 1,eff (Fig. 3b) and R 2,eff (Fig. 3c) in 18650-type cells show oscillating boundary frequencies spanning an order of magnitude under varying battery states. By comparison, coin-cell architectures (Fig. 3e and f) exhibit even significantly higher variability, with boundary frequencies diverging across two orders of magnitude (R 1,eff 10–2000 Hz; R 2,eff lower bound: 1–500 Hz). Such state-dependent shifts in the bounded frequencies originate from the dispersion in relaxation times of the electrochemical processes and the uncertainty in non-linear parameterization via ECM or DRT analysis. Both R 1,ECM and R 2,ECM are promising candidates for thermal diagnostics due to their high thermal sensitivities (>3 % °C−1). However, R 1,ECM is selected as the baseline for thermal detection because its associated processes occur over a shorter timescale, minimizing overlap with low-frequency processes and enabling more rapid and reliable measurement. Assuming that electrochemical processes comprise serially cascaded subprocesses with continuous and independent relaxation time distributions, the real components of impedance represent the cumulative resistance for all processes with relaxation time faster than the observed frequency. The differential in real impedance between two bounded frequencies (R eff) approximates the cumulative impedance of the process cluster within the corresponding frequency interval. The R eff serves as a reliable candidate to track the thermal behavior of R 1,ECM, while circumventing the complexities of global fitting. This approximation not only reduces the data dimensionality and modeling complexity but also enables the establishment of explicit low-dimensional mappings between internal temperature and frequency-domain signals. 3.2.3 Construction of low-dimensional mapping Optimization of relaxation timescale parameters for electrochemical process clusters—specifically center frequency and bandwidth (Δlog f)—balances thermal sensitivity against robustness. Thermal sensitivity was evaluated through contour density along the temperature axis on the contour maps of R eff (Figs. S6–S8). Narrower bandwidths (Δlog f = log1.25, log3.16) localize thermally sensitive frequency domains but exacerbate susceptibility to spectral noise—manifested as contour line discontinuities, while expanded bandwidths (Δlog f = log5, log10) trade marginal sensitivity loss for enhanced parametric robustness. A Δlog f = log10 bandwidth prioritized for practical implementation balances thermal sensitivity and measurement artifacts, and yields stationary central frequencies across SOC, SOH, cathode materials, and configurations (Fig. 4 ), supporting the feasibility of establishing generalized temperature-impedance mapping for cross-scenario diagnostics. Central frequency selection prioritizes sensitivity and acquisition time. 18650-type cells exhibit pronounced thermal sensitivity with the lower frequency limit in the 10–100 Hz regime (Fig. 4a–h), while coin cells shift to 5–50 Hz (Fig. 4i–l). Three representative process clusters—defined by frequency windows of [398.1–3981 Hz], [1000–100 Hz], and [500–50 Hz]—were analyzed and compared with R 1,ECM (Fig. 4b, d, f, h, j, and l). Approximate cluster resistances to the three process clusters, R eff, demonstrate strong correlation with surface ion transport resistance but distinct thermal sensitivities. The R eff,3981/398.1, predominantly reflecting interfacial contact resistance, yields low temperature dependence. R eff,1000/100 and R eff,500/50, both respecting part of the ionic transport process resistance, exhibit marked Arrhenius-type sensitivity (Figs. S9–S12). R eff,1000/100, approximate resistance to process clusters with relaxation time ranging from 1000 Hz to 100 Hz, was finally selected as the optimal fuzzy variable, due to a 50 %–100 % reduction in impedance acquisition time compared to the low-frequency alternative. 3.3 Cross-scenario adaptation Validation across diverse SOC (20 %–100 %), SOH (100 %–80 %), and cell architecture (Figs. S9–S12, Table S2) demonstrates that R eff,1000/100 adheres to Arrhenius-type thermal behavior. Activation energies (E a) are 39.72, 41.78, and 42.85 kJ mol−1 for 18650-type cells at 20 %, 50 %, and 100 % SOC, respectively, with aged cells demonstrating E a = 43.86±2.47 kJ mol−1 (Fig. S12 and Table S2). Coin-type cells exhibit lower E a = 25.82±1.22 kJ mol−1 (<10 % variability across capacities/cathodes). Limited E a variance across states supports cross-scenario adaptation, though Arrhenius behavior reduces sensitivity and concomitant expansion prediction intervals at elevated temperatures. The fuzzy variable, R eff,1000/100, is normalized to quantitatively analyze the cross-scenario adaptability (Fig. 5 ) as follows. (1) R eff , f 1 / f 2 = Δ Re ( f 1 , f 2 , T ) Δ Re ( f 1 , f 2 , T ref ) - 1 × 100 % (2) R eff , f 1 / f 2 = exp E a R 1 T - 1 T ref Based on the above formulae, ΔRe(f 1, f 2, T) represents the difference of the real parts between discrete frequencies f 1 and f 2 at temperature T. E a and R represent activation energy and universal gas constant, respectively. It should be noted that the R eff reflects the influence of a volume-averaged internal temperature, which is more indicative of the overall thermal health of the cell than localized readings (further discussion in Supplementary Note S4). The mechanism-constrained and explicit mapping and detailed values of the parameters are listed in Table S2 and Supplementary Note S3. Mappings derived from single samples demonstrate robustness across samples and SOC ranges (20 %–100 %), maintaining prediction fidelity within ±2 °C across 25–70 °C (Fig. 5a, b, d, and e). Systematic conservative prediction emerges in degraded cells (T real−T pred, cyclically aged: −10 °C; thermally aged: −12 °C; Fig. 5c, f, g, and j), which is potentially attributed to increased activation energy from SEI evolution (Table S2) but provides a built-in safety buffer in practical thermal management implementations. Coin-cell mappings exhibit generalizability across cathode materials and capacities despite amplified deviations (Fig. 5h, i, k, and l). Activation energy heterogeneity between degraded and fresh cells is effectively mitigated through increasing cell populations (Fig. 5m and o), achieving temperature predictions within ±1.0 °C at 30 °C and ±4.0 °C at 60 °C (95 % prediction intervals) across SOC and SOH. The framework’s efficiency is further underscored by its adaptability to coin-type cells (Fig. 5n and p)—only 24 profiles (4 cells × 6 temperatures) achieve remarkable ±2 °C (40 °C) and ±5 °C (60 °C) accuracy across cathodes (NCM and LCO) and capacities (45–125 mA h) without recalibration. This minimal data requirement facilitates high-throughput diagnostics, underscoring its scalability for industrial applications where rapid deployment across diverse cell specifications is critical. 3.4 Online monitoring validation Online capability of the fuzzy physics-informed strategy was validated through dynamic operational tests using the mapping in Fig. 5(o). Stepwise current-increment charging (0.5 to 2 A; Fig. 6 a) demonstrated sub-second acquisition of ∼6 s per EIS measurement using laboratory-grade instrumentation, accompanied by negligible computational overhead. Each current transition was instantaneously detected, ensuring timely and robust thermal signature acquisition and thus facilitating real-time thermal monitoring under dynamic operating conditions. During the initial 3-min rest phase, fuzzy physics-derived temperatures exhibited <0.2 °C deviation from thermocouples, demonstrating high online fidelity of the proposed mapping. A 0.5 °C core-surface gradient emerged after 3 min at 0.5 A (0.42 C-rate), escalating to a critical 3 °C at 2.0 A—highlighting thermal management challenges in energy-dense systems. Thermal transient experiments (50 to 30 °C; Fig. 6b) confirmed the robustness and high accuracy of the methodology across a broad temperature range. Upon abrupt environmental cooling from 50 to 30 °C, fuzzy physics-derived temperatures and thermocouple-detected surface measurements exhibit synchronous core/surface declines, with 5 °C differentials during initial cooling. These validate the fidelity of the strategy across a wide thermally operational window (30–50 °C) while revealing critical thermal asymmetries under dynamic thermal perturbations. Galvanostatic cycling protocols spanning 80 % to 20 % SOC demonstrated operational resilience of the fuzzy physics-informed temperature evaluation framework (Fig. 6c). During initial phases, fuzzy physics-derived temperatures maintain <0.4 °C core-surface differentials with thermocouple-acquired surface measurements across 20 %–80 % SOC. Subsequent cycling revealed 3 °C gradients at 2.0 A charging (1.67 C-rate), while this differential would even intensify quadratically under fast-charging protocols. Irregular protocols (Fig. 6d) showed internal heating rates (0.8 °C min−1) doubling surface rates during high-current phases, putting considerable bias in thermal management decisions. These findings challenge the sufficiency of surface temperature monitoring, underscoring the necessity of internal thermal data acquisition to preemptively address safety-critical thermal heterogeneities in high-energy-density systems. Systematic validation confirms that the fuzzy physics-informed EIS framework achieves real-time internal temperature diagnostics with seconds-scale resolution, stability across 30–50 °C, and robustness to 20 %–80 % SOC. Rapid high-fidelity acquisition, environmental adaptability, and SOC invariance position this framework as a compelling candidate for non-invasive internal temperature monitoring in operational energy storage systems. It should be highlighted here that the early detection of internal temperature deviations—before reaching critical thresholds—is of paramount importance in preventing thermal runaway. Even small increases in internal temperature, if detected early and accurately, can enable timely battery management system intervention to mitigate further thermal escalation. In this regard, the high fidelity, rapid response, and internal sensitivity of our frequency-domain thermal monitoring framework offer a distinct advantage over surface-based measurements, especially under practical operating conditions where early warning is most actionable. 3.5 Comparative analysis: Single-frequency, full-spectra, and fuzzy physics-informed approaches Diagnostic performance of the fuzzy physics-informed approach for internal temperature estimation was rigorously evaluated against conventional frequency-domain strategies: operationally simplistic single-frequency methodologies and physically comprehensive full-spectra approaches. As illustrated in Fig. 7 (a), the fuzzy physics-informed framework acquires impedance signals at two strategically selected frequencies within relaxation time intervals of surface ion transport processes. It isolates thermally sensitive electrochemical variables by calculating the difference in real impedance (ΔRe) to approximate cumulative process cluster circumventing spectral redundancy as discussed in Section 2.2.2. While no longer assigned to discrete processes, this approach retains monotonic temperature dependence without the need for implicit decoupling of overlapping processes, achieving computational efficiency and robustness against fitting instabilities and model dependence. This dual-frequency strategy achieves temporal efficiency through streamlined data acquisition, reducing prediction latency to 6 s—a 20-fold improvement over full-spectrum ECM analysis requiring >120 s for relaxation time characterization (Figs. S13–S15). Consequently, cross-scenario generalizability is demonstrated via inherited monotonic thermal dependencies from fundamental electrochemical processes, sustaining diagnostic fidelity across wide SOC variations (20 %–100 %) (Fig. 7b). The framework’s parsimonious parameterization further mitigates error propagation inherent to overdetermined models, ensuring algorithmic robustness under operational extremes. Single-frequency methodology [39,40] (Fig. 7d and Figs. S16–S18) minimizes acquisition time but exhibits heightened susceptibility to systemic interference (e.g., inductive artifacts from instrumentation). While certain metrics show thermal correlation, significant stochastic variability diminishes measurement reliability except within narrow operational bounds (Fig. 7e and f), fundamentally constraining cross-scenario applicability. Full-spectra characterization [41–44] (Fig. 7g) resolves comprehensive battery dynamics but incurs prohibitive computational complexity. Though ECM/DRT-derived parameters (R SEI, g(τ)) display Arrhenius-type thermal sensitivity, redundant parameterization (e.g., contact resistance, double-layer contributions) degrades thermal resolution through error amplification during nonlinear regression (Fig. 7h and i). This manifests as computational latency and algorithmic fragility in real-world applications. Thus, the fuzzy physics-informed approach exhibits superiority over conventional strategies and manifests in critical dimensions (Fig. 7c). (i) Its physical interpretability circumvents systemic noise susceptibility and ensures robustness across operational extremes and heterogeneous systems. (ii) Explicit inference and fuzzification of thermally sensitive electro-chemical processes alleviate the computational intractability to satisfy online monitoring acquisition demands. (iii) Mechanism-constrained identification of frequency-domain signatures enhances transferability to unexplored electrochemical systems while minimizing dependence on labelled datasets. 4 Conclusions This study establishes a paradigm-shifting framework for battery thermal monitoring through fuzzy physics-informed methodology, reconciling the longstanding compromise among diagnostic fidelity, computational efficiency, and cross-scenario generalizability. By prioritizing thermally dominant relaxation processes while mitigating parametric redundancy, this strategy achieves high accuracy (±1 °C around 30 °C; ±4 °C around 60 °C) across diverse operational conditions (SOC 20 %–100 %, SOH 80 %–100 %), coupled with rapid signature acquisition at seconds-scale latency, which is promising for battery thermal analytics in safety-critical applications. Experiment validation across 18650-type and coin-type cells (Fig. 5) confirms universal adherence to Arrhenius kinetics, yielding conservative error distributions that proactively identify thermal anomalies—a capability absent in existing monitoring paradigms. Furthermore, field testing under industrial operating conditions (30–50 °C, 20 %–80 % SOC; Fig. 6) confirms the framework’s viability for non-invasive, high-fidelity, and real-time diagnostics in operational energy storage systems. It should be emphasized that the primary value of this framework lies in its early-stage diagnostic capability—detecting small but meaningful internal temperature deviations before they escalate into safety-critical events. In this context, the ability to detect internal thermal fluctuation with high fidelity and rapid response—even when surface temperatures remain within safe margins—provides a crucial advantage over conventional thermocouple-based monitoring systems. This framework establishes a universal paradigm for real-time diagnostics in emerging electrochemical systems. Its mechanism-constrained variable selection—balancing physical interpretability with computational efficiency—extends beyond thermal monitoring to enable non-invasive identification of degradation precursors. The latent diagnostic capability of frequency-domain analytics necessitates advanced protocols to decipher their comprehensive electrochemical signatures. coredata.dc:description: Accurate real-time monitoring of internal temperature in lithium-ion batteries remains critical for preventing thermal runaway, as conventional approaches sacrifice either computational efficiency or cross-scenario robustness. We present a generalized fuzzy physics-informed framework that distills thermally sensitive electrochemical processes while circumventing redundant physical constraints, thereby establishing an explicit mechanism-constrained mapping between frequency-domain signals and internal temperature. This framework facilitates online thermal estimation, with dynamic validations in LiFePO4/graphite 18650-type cells confirming real-time capability with near-instantaneous acquisition (∼6 s per measurement), exceptional accuracy (±0.5 °C) within the operational temperature range (30–50 °C), and operational resilience across 20 %–80 % state-of-charge. The framework maintains predictive fidelity (±1.0 °C at 30 °C and ±4.0 °C at 60 °C, 95 % prediction intervals) across 80 %–100 % state-of-health while demonstrating adaptability to cathode materials and structural architectures. This strategy resolves the competing imperatives of physical interpretability, computational efficiency, and cross-scenario generalizability, offering a universal paradigm for embedded thermal management in safety-critical applications.

coredata.dc:title: Fuzzy physics-informed thermal diagnostics via non-invasive frequency-domain signature distillation in high-energy-density batteries
